comments.author: Patrick
comments.content: Looking forward to trying this!

comments.author: michelle moscatel
comments.content: how do you make vegetarian tangine thanks Michelle

comments.author: Lauren
comments.content: I'd never heard of this before but it looks and sounds great.  I'll have to try it.  Thanks!

comments.author: Healthy Foods Blog
comments.content: The moment this blog loaded, the first word that came out of my mouth is "Wow!". Well I guess, you know already why I did say that. It really looks brilliantly delicious.

comments.author: Alessandra
comments.content: Sounds good! I am also addicted to smoked paprika, it is amazing! :-)

comments.author: Esha
comments.content: this looks pretty similar to Indian coriander chutney!

comments.author: The Cooking Ninja
comments.content: I have to say, it's quite true that if you grind your spices or paste in mortar & pestle, it tastes somehow a lot better than using a food processor. Till this day, my mom still grinds her spices with it. However sometimes she does uses food processor when she is pressed for time.

comments.author: Deborah Soffel
comments.content: Love that stuff, could eat it with a spoon!

comments.author: Natasha Cardinez-Singh
comments.content: Must love a recipe that's simple to make yet looks so vibrant and delicious. Can't wait to try!

comments.author: Cajun Chef Ryan
comments.content:
It has my vote for a top sauce indeed! You had me at fresh chopped cilantro!

Bonne appetite!
CCR
=:~)

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Hey Esha - I could see why you would think that based on reading the ingredients, but the actual taste is totally different. More of a Mediterranean flavor instead of the pure herbal taste of coriander chutney. Give it a try and let me know what you think!

comments.author: Danielle
comments.content: I really like what you did to kick up an otherwise so-so sauce, Michael. The smoked paprika, the ginger and the chile flakes in particular. I could slather this on my mailbox and it would taste good!

comments.author: Xiaolu @ 6 Bittersweets
comments.content: This sauce sounds fascinating. I wish I could immediately taste it from the screen, but I guess I'll have to make it for myself 8).

comments.author: thepinkpeppercorn
comments.content: Oooh!  I am so glad you wrote about this!

comments.author: Richard
comments.content: The sauce looks fantastic, can't wait to try!!!!

comments.author: soph
comments.content: Yes, how do you make the tagine?!

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content:
Basically I just braised the vegetables and pre-cooked chickpeas with harissa and preserved lemon... next time I make something like that I'll write out a recipe.

Thanks,
Michael

comments.author: girlfromvalley
comments.content:
Tried this for the first time today,and so followed the recipe precisely.
Sauce of the year?
But worth doing again?-probably.

comments.author: AZ
comments.content:
Hi,

I made this tonight, and you're right, I've never tried this sauce before so I have nothing to compare it with. What exactly does it taste like? What's the most dominant flavour (e.g. cumin, parsely etc).

Also, does it taste better the following day?

Thanks,
AZ

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Hey AZ - I'd say that all of the flavors should come through in balance. In particular, I want to be able to taste that metallic twang of the saffron in the mix with all of the herbaceous flavors.

comments.author: Wendy
comments.content: Love the sauce, but want to make the veggies to go with it. I'm trying to follow your post above, but not sure how to interpret what you wrote. Did you braise the veggies and cook the chickpeas separately? Or throw the pre-cooked chick peas in with the raw veggies and lemon? How did you make your harissa?

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Hey Wendy - honestly, it has been so long I don't remember exactly how I made that tagine, but you could do something like this: https://herbivoracious.com//2008/01/couscous-with-s.html and use the chermoula instead of the yogurt sauce.

comments.author: Lisa
comments.content: I love this tossed with roasted root vegetables! And, hailing from the South, I sometimes toss with luscious sweet potato only!  It's hard to come for air....; )

comments.author: jual sambal online
comments.content:
chermoula? i think, i wanna try this recipe now. i see the photo are very interested
thank you for your share

comments.author: Gillian
comments.content: I was wondering if it was possible to pre make this sauce to use 2/3 days later? I would like to use It over Christmas but would not be able to prepare it at that time.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: That should be ok; just put it in a container and maybe cover it with a thin layer of oil and then plastic wrap to minimize oxidation so the color stays nice. Store in the refrigerator of course.
